description: From Middle English vayle, from Old French vail, from valoir (“to be worth”), from Latin valeō (“I am worth”).

examples: My house is as t’were the Caue, where the yong Out-lawe hoords the stolne vayles of his occupation  […]

entries.meaning: (chiefly in the plural, obsolete) Money given to servants by visitors; a gratuity; also vale.
examples: Do you remember, how many Rich Gowns and Petticoats, how many lac’d Pinners, Hoods, Scarfs, and Nightrails, I have given you, since the three Years you have serv’d me, together with many other Vails, Perquisites, and Profits you have enjoy’d in my Service?

description: From Middle English valen; either from Anglo-Norman valer or a clipping of avalen. Compare avale.

verbs.description: vail (third-person singular simple present vails, present participle vailing, simple past and past participle vailed)

entries.meaning: (transitive, obsolete) To lower, let fall; to allow or cause to sink.
examples: Then let them vale a bonet of their proud ſayle,And of their taunting toies reſt with il hayle.

entries.meaning: (transitive, vexillology) To lower or “dip” a carried flag or banner in a salute by a forward reducing of the angle of the pike/flagstaff with respect to the ground; in extreme instances, as when saluting a monarch, both the banner and the finial of the pike are allowed to rest upon the ground.
(intransitive, obsolete, nautical) To lower a sail, in salute or otherwise.
(transitive, obsolete) To remove as a sign of deference, as a hat.
(intransitive, obsolete) To pay homage, bow, submit, defer (to someone or something); to yield, give way (to something).
examples: Thy convenience must vail to thy neighbour’s necessity.

verbs.description: vail (third-person singular simple present vails, present participle vailing, simple past and past participle vailed)
